ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: More vocabulary, basic grammar, introduction to case system, conversation with native speaker from Syria

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The best parts of this course were the final project karaoke, looking at authentic materials, and having a conversation partner.

The weakest part of the course was the textbook which emphasizes a vocabulary for students seeking to work in the state department. 

Inshallah there will be a better textbook and more opportunities for studying dialect early on in future iterations of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who want to engage with Arabic language and culture but with the awareness that some people in the class will be more interested in using the language for business or military purposes. This was emotionally difficult for me, so I would warn other students about this.
